body:
> Have you thought that maybe the people who are picked to be GM of guilds, moderators on the discord server, and part of the focus group are people who the admins get along well with so it's easier to make progress?

Yes, it seems the admins just randomly decide some people are better than everyone else and get divine status. The fact that they let those users do everything and absolutely *refuse* to even consider letting someone else do just one of those things is what's so concerning. It's starting to resemble DefaultMods and I don't like it.

> I agree that the mods can bend or break the rules on the discord(fairly rarely)

It's not rare. They break the rules all the time, and they have zero restrictions either (no word filter, no slowmode, no having to earn roles to enter gated channels). This is definitely abused, and the admins are super strict about everyone else following them but completely okay with mods doing whatever the hell they want. And everyone else worships this setup, it's a huge circlejerk.

> Which as you said before, you can't use discord that often, so you're unable to communicate with the admins much outside of Ruqqus or Github and with the admins probably getting dozens of pings a day on Ruqqus the lack of communication might be a core issue.

Which is exactly why the admins need to actually spend more time on ruqqus rather than discord. I don't even see why they have to be the ones running that, someone else could and it would both ease their workload and open up opportunities for more than one server.
body_html:
Have you thought that maybe the people who are picked to be GM of guilds, moderators on the discord server, and part of the focus group are people who the admins get along well with so it's easier to make progress?

Yes, it seems the admins just randomly decide some people are better than everyone else and get divine status. The fact that they let those users do everything and absolutely refuse to even consider letting someone else do just one of those things is what's so concerning. It's starting to resemble DefaultMods and I don't like it.

I agree that the mods can bend or break the rules on the discord(fairly rarely)

It's not rare. They break the rules all the time, and they have zero restrictions either (no word filter, no slowmode, no having to earn roles to enter gated channels). This is definitely abused, and the admins are super strict about everyone else following them but completely okay with mods doing whatever the hell they want. And everyone else worships this setup, it's a huge circlejerk.

Which as you said before, you can't use discord that often, so you're unable to communicate with the admins much outside of Ruqqus or Github and with the admins probably getting dozens of pings a day on Ruqqus the lack of communication might be a core issue.

Which is exactly why the admins need to actually spend more time on ruqqus rather than discord. I don't even see why they have to be the ones running that, someone else could and it would both ease their workload and open up opportunities for more than one server.

parent.body:
Have you thought that maybe the people who are picked to be GM of guilds, moderators on the discord server, and part of the focus group are people who the admins get along well with so it's easier to make progress?

I can't say much about the coding because I'm not in that area of Ruqqus or the discord but I know at least Seq communicates a LOT more with Cap about the requests and usually is right there when the merge happens in case of any instant issues.

I agree that the mods can bend or break the rules on the discord(fairly rarely) but I don't see the same type of things happening on Ruqqus.  Which as you said before, you can't use discord that often, so you're unable to communicate with the admins much outside of Ruqqus or Github and with the admins probably getting dozens of pings a day on Ruqqus the lack of communication might be a core issue.

body:
I *saw* him report the links himself in the WRD mod discord, to both reddit admins (who of course didn't care) and law enforcement in 3 DIFFERENT COUNTRIES, before you even knew about them. It was about an attack sent to WRD's modmail, not trying to dispense the CP. Yeah that was a stupid for move him to bring it up on discord like that, exactly because it can easily look like something else and this could happen, which it did. It's such a serious thing that people freak out when it's mentioned and jump to conclusions and make accusations, almost like a kind of hysteria, which is what happened here. You saw one message "trust you with links that probably lead to cp" and are basing this entire thing on that. In reality he was talking about the troll modmails so he was actually trying to get someone to promise that they *wouldn't* go to the CP links if he sent them to him.

You need to quit saying someone's guilty of something just because you suspect it *could* be the case. This is the most severe incident but it's happened before too (ex. firexq was a "pedo" for disagreeing with you about a guild ban, jason "doxxed" because he mentioned Bardfinn's name ([which you did too btw](https://ruqqus.com/+averageredditor/post/4ifs/bardfinn-says-ruqqus-is-an-amplifier/fnsx)), klenny was permabanned and doxxed by you because he broke the 10 gm limit with alts, which was not against the rules at that time, and dgk was banned for being in "bad faith" because you two didn't have the greatest history). You're acting like a reddit mod when you do this. Stop jumping to conclusions when you don't know the full story, especially when you block the person from even being able to tell you their "excuses" as you call them. This was a very serious accusation you made, and you harassed Ali into leaving the whole internet *and* could potentially cause him to have to deal with a lot of shit in real life because of your accusations. He is *not* doing cp. Having suspicion and a little bit of evidence is reason to *investigate* something, not come to a conclusion and take action without solid evidence, especially something this serious. Even if he *was* doing CP, you don't have nearly enough proof to take this big of an action about it.

post.body:
There's a lot of accounts on here that are very active and as such have a lot of followers. Usually it's like 20-45. Almost all the people I recognize as power users are in this group. However there's also a group of accounts that is mostly newer than those, posts less...and the top ones have about 70-120 followers (as many as the admins)!

This doesn't really make any sense to me. Here's a list for reference. I excluded admins and novelty accounts:

1. @eagle 110 subscribers, last active one month ago

2. @carpathianflorist 77 subscribers

3. @NeonRevolt 73 subscribers, last active 2 months ago

4. @Inaki 31 subscribers...1 post 5 months ago and zero comments??!!

5. @AngstKitten 20 subscribers, last posted 1 month ago and only comments a couple times per month

6. @Sentient 18 subscribers, last active 3 months ago

For comparison, here's a list of ones I think actually make sense. Notice the huge gap in followers between these and the unexplained ones:

1. @stars_in_blue_major 41 subscribers

2. @TrumpVoter1 32 subscribers (private profile which may cause a small drop)

3. @CrystalVulpine 31 subscribers

4. @LlamaBean 23 subscribers

5. @Meguminnnn 23 subscribers (seems a tiny bit excessive because he's not *that* active but that could just be luck)

6. @AsininePorcupine 20 subscribers

7. @no_chill 20 subscribers

8. @VILLAIN 19 subscribers

9. @Bidpots 17 subscribers

What's also weird is how big the gap is. There's **no one** in the 45-65 range. It jumps immediately from 41 all the way to 73. And *all* the ones in the 70-120 range are these unexplained cases.

I really don't see how this works. I've never even heard of many of the ones on the first list, all the power users are on the second one. So I'm not really sure what's going on here. Anyone have any guesses?

post.body:
There's a lot of accounts on here that are very active and as such have a lot of followers. Usually it's like 20-45. Almost all the people I recognize as power users are in this group. However there's also a group of accounts that is mostly newer than those, posts less...and the top ones have about 70-120 followers (as many as the admins)!

This doesn't really make any sense to me. Here's a list for reference. I excluded admins and novelty accounts:

1. @eagle 110 subscribers, last active one month ago

2. @carpathianflorist 77 subscribers

3. @NeonRevolt 73 subscribers, last active 2 months ago

4. @Inaki 31 subscribers...1 post 5 months ago and zero comments??!!

5. @AngstKitten 20 subscribers, last posted 1 month ago and only comments a couple times per month

6. @Sentient 18 subscribers, last active 3 months ago

For comparison, here's a list of ones I think actually make sense. Notice the huge gap in followers between these and the unexplained ones:

1. @stars_in_blue_major 41 subscribers

2. @TrumpVoter1 32 subscribers (private profile which may cause a small drop)

3. @CrystalVulpine 31 subscribers

4. @LlamaBean 23 subscribers

5. @Meguminnnn 23 subscribers (seems a tiny bit excessive because he's not *that* active but that could just be luck)

6. @AsininePorcupine 20 subscribers

7. @no_chill 20 subscribers

8. @VILLAIN 19 subscribers

9. @Bidpots 17 subscribers

What's also weird is how big the gap is. There's **no one** in the 45-65 range. It jumps immediately from 41 all the way to 73. And *all* the ones in the 70-120 range are these unexplained cases.

I really don't see how this works. I've never even heard of many of the ones on the first list, all the power users are on the second one. So I'm not really sure what's going on here. Anyone have any guesses?

parent.body: It's the same though.  Admins would rather have people they can talk to in private over issues so they can't easily be exploited and can get instant replies back.  Ruqqus doesn't have an instant reply chat yet so it's harder to communicate and get instant feedback.  Discord is currently the best alternative until that issue is settled so it makes a lot of sense that people that are able to use discord are the ones the admins look to for feedback and issue solving.  If people posted bugs and issues they found on Ruqqus there is a good chance someone will actively try to find that bug before it is patched, causing the admins to do massive amounts of cleanup.

post.body:
There's a lot of accounts on here that are very active and as such have a lot of followers. Usually it's like 20-45. Almost all the people I recognize as power users are in this group. However there's also a group of accounts that is mostly newer than those, posts less...and the top ones have about 70-120 followers (as many as the admins)!

This doesn't really make any sense to me. Here's a list for reference. I excluded admins and novelty accounts:

1. @eagle 110 subscribers, last active one month ago

2. @carpathianflorist 77 subscribers

3. @NeonRevolt 73 subscribers, last active 2 months ago

4. @Inaki 31 subscribers...1 post 5 months ago and zero comments??!!

5. @AngstKitten 20 subscribers, last posted 1 month ago and only comments a couple times per month

6. @Sentient 18 subscribers, last active 3 months ago

For comparison, here's a list of ones I think actually make sense. Notice the huge gap in followers between these and the unexplained ones:

1. @stars_in_blue_major 41 subscribers

2. @TrumpVoter1 32 subscribers (private profile which may cause a small drop)

3. @CrystalVulpine 31 subscribers

4. @LlamaBean 23 subscribers

5. @Meguminnnn 23 subscribers (seems a tiny bit excessive because he's not *that* active but that could just be luck)

6. @AsininePorcupine 20 subscribers

7. @no_chill 20 subscribers

8. @VILLAIN 19 subscribers

9. @Bidpots 17 subscribers

What's also weird is how big the gap is. There's **no one** in the 45-65 range. It jumps immediately from 41 all the way to 73. And *all* the ones in the 70-120 range are these unexplained cases.

I really don't see how this works. I've never even heard of many of the ones on the first list, all the power users are on the second one. So I'm not really sure what's going on here. Anyone have any guesses?

  5. @AngstKitten 20 subscribers, last posted 1 month ago and only comments a couple times per month

  6. @Sentient 18 subscribers, last active 3 months ago

For comparison, here's a list of ones I think actually make sense. Notice the huge gap in followers between these and the unexplained ones:

  1. @stars_in_blue_major 41 subscribers

  3. @CrystalVulpine 31 subscribers

  4. @LlamaBean 23 subscribers

What's also weird is how big the gap is. There's no one in the 45-65 range. It jumps immediately from 41 all the way to 73. And all the ones in the 70-120 range are these unexplained cases.

I really don't see how this works. I've never even heard of many of the ones on the first list, all the power users are on the second one. So I'm not really sure what's going on here. Anyone have any guesses?

parent.body:
I mean the same thing applies with the instant reply chat, it's quicker and easier to reply on discord than on Ruqqus so the issue gets solved MUCH faster.  Admins allowed people to GM certain(non-ruqqus) guilds with them because they were in an instant reply chat and could talk easily.

I wouldn't let someone GM a guild if they weren't on discord ATM because if there's an issue I want to be able to get instant replies and be able to contact them easily, and without a proper Ruqqus app with push notifications, it's hard to do that on Ruqqus.  Sentient added me as a GM to +RuqqusDiscord while he's been busy because I'm in the discord and he was able to DM me about it.  I added Friday as a GM to +Inspirational_Opossum because they're able to DM me on discord.  So I fully understand admins turning to people who are able to instantly get and reply to messages over someone they would have to babysit Ruqqus for.

body:
> but dyno is a bitch about that so it's hard to set up.

That's not the only thing though:

* Slowmode

* Ability to participate in gated channels they haven't earned the rules for

* Admins let them break the rules a lot

* Admins put their names at the very top of the server

* Admins listen to them more and have a private chat room with them

* Admins originally planned on making them junior admins on the actual site too

* Admins only let them GM their guilds or basically anything.

* Most of them were let into the focus group.

> I've only seen Angst and Megu get "special treatment" on Ruqqus as a discord mod

And is that not a problem to you?

> Seq gets "special treatment" but that's because he constantly works with Cap on issues and became a mod after he had helped so much.

Cap doesn't just let anyone help him. He only picks a few people he thinks are "worthy" enough and everyone else is pretty much warded off.

> Ruq, Luk, Nova, or Sentient

Luk is a GM on +technology and a discord mod. Ruq is part of the focus group and a discord mod. I believe Nova and/or Sentient GM a guild or two as well.

> But the "special treatment" on Ruqqus just seems to be that they're allowed to GM alongside the admins, which I see no issues with.

And the other things I listed. But just the fact that they always pick the exact same people for everything hints that they are extremely biased and respecters of persons and are starting to form a DefaultMods-like mindset.
body_html:
but dyno is a bitch about that so it's hard to set up.

That's not the only thing though:

  • Slowmode

  • Ability to participate in gated channels they haven't earned the rules for

  • Admins let them break the rules a lot

  • Admins put their names at the very top of the server

  • Admins listen to them more and have a private chat room with them

  • Admins originally planned on making them junior admins on the actual site too

  • Admins only let them GM their guilds or basically anything.

  • Most of them were let into the focus group.

I've only seen Angst and Megu get "special treatment" on Ruqqus as a discord mod

And is that not a problem to you?

Seq gets "special treatment" but that's because he constantly works with Cap on issues and became a mod after he had helped so much.

Cap doesn't just let anyone help him. He only picks a few people he thinks are "worthy" enough and everyone else is pretty much warded off.

Ruq, Luk, Nova, or Sentient

Luk is a GM on +Technology and a discord mod. Ruq is part of the focus group and a discord mod. I believe Nova and/or Sentient GM a guild or two as well.

But the "special treatment" on Ruqqus just seems to be that they're allowed to GM alongside the admins, which I see no issues with.

And the other things I listed. But just the fact that they always pick the exact same people for everything hints that they are extremely biased and respecters of persons and are starting to form a DefaultMods-like mindset.

For comparison, here's a list of ones I think actually make sense. Notice the huge gap in followers between these and the unexplained ones:

1. @stars_in_blue_major 41 subscribers

2. @TrumpVoter1 32 subscribers (private profile which may cause a small drop)

3. @CrystalVulpine 31 subscribers

4. @LlamaBean 23 subscribers

5. @Meguminnnn 23 subscribers (seems a tiny bit excessive because he's not *that* active but that could just be luck)

6. @AsininePorcupine 20 subscribers

7. @no_chill 20 subscribers

8. @VILLAIN 19 subscribers

9. @Bidpots 17 subscribers

What's also weird is how big the gap is. There's **no one** in the 45-65 range. It jumps immediately from 41 all the way to 73. And *all* the ones in the 70-120 range are these unexplained cases.

I really don't see how this works. I've never even heard of many of the ones on the first list, all the power users are on the second one. So I'm not really sure what's going on here. Anyone have any guesses?

body:
> Angst and Sentient are discord mods and generally well liked people in the community.

I don't see how being a discord mod makes you get a ton of extra followers on ruqqus. Not only that but both are hardly active at all on ruqqus, and the discord might as well be a completely different website at this point.

> Carp is possibly the most famous person on ruqqus.

I don't recognize him that much. All the people I know very well save for angst are on the second list.

> The rest 3 got them from recruiting, timing

I recruited over 100 people.
